list.title: Question 3
list.content: Letf(x)=x3f(x) = x^3f(x)=x3andg(x)=2x−1g(x) = 2x - 1g(x)=2x−1, forx∈Rx \in \mathbb{R}x∈R.Findg−1(x)g^{-1}(x)g−1(x).[2]Find(g∘f)(x)(g\circ f)(x)(g∘f)(x).[2]Solve the equation(g∘f)(x)=0(g\circ f)(x) = 0(g∘f)(x)=0.[2]
list.markScheme:
If we solve the equation(g∘g−1)(x)=x(g\circ g^{-1})(x) = x(g∘g−1)(x)=xfory=g−1(x)y = g^{-1}(x)y=g−1(x), we getg(g−1(x))=xg(y)=x2y−1=x2y=x+1y=x+12\begin{aligned}
g(g^{-1}(x)) &= x \\[12pt]
g(y) &= x \\[12pt]
2y - 1 &= x \\[12pt]
2y &= x + 1 \\[6pt]
y &= \dfrac{x + 1}{2} \hspace{1.9em} \\
\end{aligned}g(g−1(x))g(y)2y−12yy​=x=x=x=x+1=2x+1​​g−1(x)=x+12\answer{g^{-1}(x) = \dfrac{x+1}{2}} \hspace{0.6em}g−1(x)=2x+1​​We have(g∘f)(x)=g(f(x))=g(x3)=2x3−1\begin{aligned}
(g\circ f)(x) &= g(f(x)) \\[6pt]
&= g(x^3) \\[6pt]
&\answer{= 2x^3-1} \hspace{1.1em}\end{aligned}(g∘f)(x)​=g(f(x))=g(x3)=2x3−1​​Solving the equation(g∘f)(x)=0(g\circ f)(x) = 0(g∘f)(x)=0forxxx, we obtain2x3−1=0[by part (b)]\begin{aligned}
\hspace{5.5em} 2x^3-1 &= 0 \hspace{3em} [\text{by part (b)}] \\
\end{aligned}2x3−1​=0[by part (b)]​x≈0.794[by using G.D.C.]\hspace{12.2em} \answer{x \approx 0.794} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]x≈0.794​[by using G.D.C.]

list.title: Question 4
list.content: Letf(x)=x2−2x−8f(x) = x^2 - 2x - 8f(x)=x2−2x−8, forx∈Rx \in \mathbb{R}x∈R.Write down theyyy-intercept of the graph ofy=f(x)y = f(x)y=f(x).[1]Solve the equationf(x)=0f(x) = 0f(x)=0.[3]Find the equation of the axis of symmetry of the graph ofy=f(x)y = f(x)y=f(x).[2]
list.markScheme:
Evaluatingy=f(x)y = f(x)y=f(x)forx=0x = 0x=0, we havey=f(0)=02−2(0)−8=−8\begin{aligned}
\hspace{6em} y &= f(0) \\[6pt]
&= 0^2 - 2(0) - 8 \\[6pt]
&= -8\end{aligned}y​=f(0)=02−2(0)−8=−8​Hence the pointP(0,−8)\answer{\mathrm{P}(0,-8)}P(0,−8)​is theyyy-intercept of the graph ofy=f(x)y = f(x)y=f(x).Solving the equationf(x)=0f(x) = 0f(x)=0forxxx, we getx2−2x−8=0(x+2)(x−4)=0\begin{aligned}
x^2 - 2x - 8 &= 0 \hspace{4.8em} \\[6pt]
(x + 2)(x - 4) &= 0 \\
\end{aligned}x2−2x−8(x+2)(x−4)​=0=0​x=−2,4\hspace{2.8em} \answer{x = -2,\hspace{0.25em} 4}x=−2,4​Using the method of completing the square, we havef(x)=x2−2x−8=[(x−1)2−1]−8=(x−1)2−9\begin{aligned}
\hspace{6.7em} f(x) &= x^2 - 2x - 8 \\[6pt]
&= \big[(x - 1)^2 - 1\big] - 8 \\[6pt]
&= (x - 1)^2 - 9\end{aligned}f(x)​=x2−2x−8=[(x−1)2−1]−8=(x−1)2−9​Hence the axis of symmetry of the
graph ofy=f(x)y = f(x)y=f(x)isx=1\answer{x = 1}x=1​

list.title: Question 5
list.content: Letf(x)=x2+2f(x) = x^2 + 2f(x)=x2+2andg(x)=x−3g(x) = x - 3g(x)=x−3, forx∈Rx \in \mathbb{R}x∈R.Findf(3)f(3)f(3).[2]Find(g∘f)(3)(g\circ f)(3)(g∘f)(3).[2]Findg−1(x)g^{-1}(x)g−1(x).[2]
list.markScheme:
Evaluatingf(x)=x2+2f(x) = x^2 + 2f(x)=x2+2forx=3x = 3x=3, we getf(3)=32+2=9+2=11\begin{aligned}
\hspace{0.6em} f(3) &= 3^2 + 2 \\[6pt]
&= 9 + 2 \\[6pt]
&\answer{= 11}\end{aligned}f(3)​=32+2=9+2=11​​Evaluating(g∘f)(x)=g(f(x))(g\circ f)(x) = g(f(x))(g∘f)(x)=g(f(x))forx=3x = 3x=3, we obtain(g∘f)(3)=g(f(3))=g(11)[by part (a)]=11−3=8\begin{aligned}
\hspace{6.4em} (g\circ f)(3) &= g(f(3)) \\[6pt]
&= g(11) \hspace{3em} [\text{by part (a)}] \\[6pt]
&= 11 - 3 \\[6pt]
&\answer{= 8}\end{aligned}(g∘f)(3)​=g(f(3))=g(11)[by part (a)]=11−3=8​​If we solve the equation(g∘g−1)(x)=x(g\circ g^{-1})(x) = x(g∘g−1)(x)=xfory=g−1(x)y = g^{-1}(x)y=g−1(x), we findg(g−1(x))=xg(y)=xy−3=xy=x+3\begin{aligned}
g(g^{-1}(x)) &= x \\[6pt]
g(y) &= x \\[6pt]
y - 3 &= x \\[6pt]
y &= x + 3 \hspace{2.1em} \\
\end{aligned}g(g−1(x))g(y)y−3y​=x=x=x=x+3​g−1(x)=x+3\answer{g^{-1}(x) = x+3} \hspace{0.8em}g−1(x)=x+3​

list.title: Question 6
list.content: Letf(x)=(x−3)(x+1)f(x) = (x - 3)(x + 1)f(x)=(x−3)(x+1), forx∈Rx \in \mathbb{R}x∈R.For the graph offff, find:theyyy-intercept;[2]thexxx-intercepts;[2]the coordinates of the vertex.[3]
list.markScheme:
Evaluatingf(x)=(x−3)(x+1)f(x) = (x - 3)(x + 1)f(x)=(x−3)(x+1)forx=0x = 0x=0, we havef(0)=(0−3)(0+1)=(−3)(1)=−3\begin{aligned}
\hspace{4em} f(0) &= (0 - 3)(0 + 1) \\[6pt] 
&= (-3)(1) \\[6pt]
&= -3\end{aligned}f(0)​=(0−3)(0+1)=(−3)(1)=−3​Hence theyyy-intercept isA(0,−3)\answer{\mathrm{A}(0,-3)}A(0,−3)​Solving the equationf(x)=0f(x) = 0f(x)=0forxxx, we have(x−3)(x+1)=0x=−1,3\begin{aligned}
(x - 3)(x + 1) &= 0 \\[6pt]
x &= -1,\hspace{0.25em} 3 \hspace{1.5em}\end{aligned}(x−3)(x+1)x​=0=−1,3​Hence thexxx-intercepts areB(−1,0)\answer{\mathrm{B}(-1,0)}B(−1,0)​andC(3,0)\answer{\mathrm{C}(3,0)}C(3,0)​Using the method of completing the square, we havef(x)=(x−3)(x+1)=x2−2x−3=[(x−1)2−1]−3=(x−1)2−4\begin{aligned}
\hspace{5.8em} f(x) &= (x - 3)(x + 1) \\[6pt]
&= x^2 - 2x - 3 \\[6pt]
&= \big[(x-1)^2 - 1\big] - 3 \\[6pt]
&= (x-1)^2 - 4\end{aligned}f(x)​=(x−3)(x+1)=x2−2x−3=[(x−1)2−1]−3=(x−1)2−4​Hence the coordinates of the vertex
are(1,−4)\answer{(1,-4)}(1,−4)​

list.content: Letf(x)=2xf(x) = 2xf(x)=2x,g(x)=4x+6g(x) = 4x + 6g(x)=4x+6andh(x)=(f∘g)(x)h(x) = (f\circ g)(x)h(x)=(f∘g)(x), forx∈Rx \in \mathbb{R}x∈R.Findh(x)h(x)h(x).[2]Findh−1(x)h^{-1}(x)h−1(x).[3]

\hspace{2.3em} h(x) &= (f\circ g)(x) \\[6pt]
&= f(g(x)) \\[6pt]
&= f(4x+6) \\[6pt]
&= 2(4x+6) \\[6pt]
&\answer{= 8x+12}\end{aligned}h(x)​=(f∘g)(x)=f(g(x))=f(4x+6)=2(4x+6)=8x+12​​If we solve the equation(h∘h−1)(x)=x(h\circ h^{-1})(x) = x(h∘h−1)(x)=xfory=h−1(x)y = h^{-1}(x)y=h−1(x), we geth(h−1(x))=xh(y)=x8y+12=x8y=x−12y=x−128\begin{aligned}

y &= \dfrac{x-12}{8} \hspace{1.3em} \\
\end{aligned}h(h−1(x))h(y)8y+128yy​=x=x=x=x−12=8x−12​​h−1(x)=x−128\answer{h^{-1}(x) = \dfrac{x-12}{8}}h−1(x)=8x−12​​

list.content:

(P\circ D)(10)&=2+\dfrac{10}{2}\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{4mm}\\
&\hspace{0.28em}\answer{=7}\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{9mm}\end{aligned}(P∘D)(10)​=2+210​=7​​This result means that after 10 minutes, the ocean pressure outside the submarine is 7 atmospheres.\answer{\text{This result means that after 10 minutes, the ocean pressure outside the submarine is 7 atmospheres.}}This result means that after 10 minutes, the ocean pressure outside the submarine is 7 atmospheres.​

list.title: Question 50
list.content:

produces,NNN, can be modelled by the functionN(t)=3t−9N(t)=3t-9N(t)=3t−9wheretttis the number of hours the factory operates per day, with a minimum of 3
hours.The profit the company makes,PPP, in dollars, depends on the number of
tyres produced, and is modelled by the functionP(N)=60N−850P(N)=60N-850P(N)=60N−850whereNNNis the number of tyres produced.Find the company's profit or loss if it operates for666hours per
day.[2]Find the company's profit in terms of the hours of operation per

to the nearest hour.[2]

N(6) &= 3(6)-9 = 9\\
\end{aligned}N(6)​=3(6)−9=9​Thus, the profit is given by P(9)P(9)=60(9)−850=−310\begin{aligned}
 P(9) &= 60(9)-850 = -310
 \end{aligned}P(9)​=60(9)−850=−310​Therefore, operating666hours a day, the company has a loss:$−310\answer{\$\hspace{0.07em}-310}$−310​The profit in terms of the hours of operation per day can be found
by the composite functionP∘NP\circ NP∘N. Hence, we get(P∘N)(t)=P(N(t))=P(3t−9)=60(3t−9)−850(P∘N)(t)=180t−1390(1)\begin{aligned}
(P\circ N)(t) &= P(N(t)) \rule[-3mm]{0pt}{4mm}\\
&= P(3t-9) \rule[-3mm]{0pt}{7mm}\\
&= 60(3t-9)-850\rule[-3mm]{0pt}{7mm}\\
&\hspace{-5em}\answer{(P\circ N)(t) = 180\hspace{0.05em}t-1390}\hspace{5em}{(1)}\rule[0mm]{0pt}{4mm}\end{aligned}(P∘N)(t)​=P(N(t))=P(3t−9)=60(3t−9)−850(P∘N)(t)=180t−1390​(1)​The company has a positive profit if (1) is greater than 0. Hence(P∘N)(t)>0180t−1390>0t>1390180t>7.72.\begin{aligned}
(P\circ N)(t) &>0\rule[-3mm]{0pt}{4mm}\\
180t-1390 &> 0 \rule[-3mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\
t &> \dfrac{1390}{180} \rule[-3mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\
t &> 7.72.\rule[0mm]{0pt}{5.5mm}\end{aligned}(P∘N)(t)180t−1390tt​>0>0>1801390​>7.72.​Therefore, the
factory needs to operate8\answer{8}8​hours per day in order for the company to earn a positive profit.

list.content: Write the expression4ln⁡2−ln⁡84\ln 2 - \ln 84ln2−ln8in the form ofln⁡k\ln klnk, wherek∈Zk \in \mathbb{Z}k∈Z.[3]Hence, or otherwise, solve4ln⁡2−ln⁡8=−ln⁡(2x)4\ln 2 - \ln 8 = -\ln (2x)4ln2−ln8=−ln(2x).[3]

Using the properties of logarithms, we have4ln⁡2−ln⁡8=ln⁡(24)−ln⁡8=ln⁡16−ln⁡8=ln⁡(168)=ln⁡2\begin{aligned}

&= \ln 16 - \ln 8 \\[6pt] 
&= \ln\Big(\dfrac{16}{8}\Big) \\[9pt]
& \answer{= \ln 2}\end{aligned}4ln2−ln8​=ln(24)−ln8=ln16−ln8=ln(816​)=ln2​​Replacing the left hand side of the equation withln⁡2\ln 2ln2, we get4ln⁡2−ln⁡8=−ln⁡(2x)ln⁡2=−ln⁡(2x)−ln⁡2=ln⁡(2x)ln⁡(2−1)=ln⁡(2x)2x=2−12x=12x=14\begin{aligned}
4\ln 2 - \ln 8 &= -\ln (2x) \\[12pt]
\ln 2  &= -\ln(2x) \hspace{2.2em} \\[12pt]
-\ln 2 &= \ln(2x) \\[12pt]
\ln \big(2^{-1}\big) &= \ln(2x) \\[12pt]
2x &= 2^{-1} \\[12pt]
2x &= \dfrac 1 2 \\[13pt]
&\hspace{-0.525em} \answer{x = \dfrac{1}{4}}\end{aligned}4ln2−ln8ln2−ln2ln(2−1)2x2x​=−ln(2x)=−ln(2x)=ln(2x)=ln(2x)=2−1=21​x=41​​​

for the range, the functionP(x)P(x)P(x)is increasing andP(0)=2P(0)=2P(0)=2andP(1)=4+πP(1)=4+\piP(1)=4+π. Therefore,Range:2≤P(x)≤4+π.\begin{aligned}
\answer{\text{Range: } 2\leq P(x) \leq 4+\pi.}\\
\end{aligned}Range:2≤P(x)≤4+π.​​Let's denoteP(x)P(x)P(x)byyyy. To find the inverse we can interchange
the variablesxxxandyyyand rearrange foryyy, as followsy=2+(2+π)xx=2+(2+π)yy=x−2(2+π)P−1(x)=x−2(2+π)\begin{aligned}
y &= 2+(2+\pi)x\rule[-3mm]{0pt}{3mm}\\
